item.title: Late Night Thinks the War on Drugs Has Gone a Bit Off the Rails
item.description: The president who says he’s killing traffickers “pardoned a man who smuggled in enough cocaine to give every American resting Kash Patel face,” Josh Johnson said.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: La ‘carrera contra el tiempo’ para salvar las cintas de leyendas de la música
item.description: Problemas nuevos afectan a carretes viejos, poniendo décadas de historia en peligro. Un hombre, armado con secadoras de cabello y una pasión por experimentar, está liderando la lucha por rescatarlos.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario and Peter Fisher

media:content.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times

item.title: Word of the Day: prosperity
item.description: This word has appeared in 600 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: When a Murder Hornet Becomes a Tasty Meal
item.description: A researcher found that a Japanese pond frog is impervious to the stings of the northern giant hornet, even when it goes down the hatch.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: Taiwan’s Opposition Leader, Once for Independence, Turns Toward China
item.description: She says Taiwan must embrace its Chinese heritage to avoid war. Her critics say she wants to steer the island into Beijing’s orbit.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei

media:content.media:description: The Nationalist Party leader Cheng Li-wun in her office in Taipei, Taiwan, in November.

item.description: Cheng Li-wun attending a memorial ceremony for Chiang Kai-shek in Taoyuan, in November.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 4, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 4, 2025.

item.title: Ground Incursions and Back-Channel Meetings Reshape Israel–Syria Relations
item.description: Thirteen people, including two children, were killed following an Israeli military operation in Beit Jinn, in western Damascus countryside.

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The main intersection in Khan Arnabeh in Quneitra Governorate, Syria in August.

item.title: ¿Spotify acaba de llamarme viejo? La ’edad sonora’ causa debate
item.description: Se ha vuelto una tradición de Spotify confeccionar evaluaciones artificiosas y diseñadas para que sus usuarios compartan los resultados en las redes sociales. Este año es la “edad sonora”.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher

item.title: Erika Kirk Takes on the Mantle of Leading Turning Point USA
item.description: The widow of Charlie Kirk promoted conciliation and portrayed her late husband as a seeker of dialogue.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Erika Kirk Takes on Leading Turning Point USA
item.description: During the DealBook Summit, Erika Kirk, Charlie Kirk’s widow, said balancing family and career was an illusion but that she was comfortable being both a single mother and the leader of Turning Point USA.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 4, 2025
item.description: Stephan Prock makes his New York Times Crossword debut abetted, sorry, assisted by Jeff Chen.
item.dc:creator: Deb Amlen

media:content.media:credit: Gerard Julien/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Here’s hoping that these people manage to find their way.

item.title: Trump Pardons Developer Prosecuted by His Administration
item.description: This summer, Trump administration officials had lauded the indictment of Timothy J. Leiweke as an effort to root out corruption and unfair business practices.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Lindsey Wasson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Timothy J. Leiweke, a founder and former chief executive of Oak View Group, in Seattle in October 2021.

item.title: Armed Volunteer Charged in Fatal Shooting at Utah ‘No Kings’ Protest
item.description: The volunteer is facing one count of manslaughter after he tried to confront a man who was carrying an AR-15 style rifle at the Salt Lake City event in June.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Karolina Wojtasik/Bravo/NBCUniversal, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Arthur Folasa Ah Loo, who was known as Afa, appeared on Season 17 of “Project Runway” in 2019.

item.title: What to Know About Putin’s Visit to India as Oil Trade Dries Up
item.description: The Trump administration, which crippled Russia’s oil sales to India with sanctions, will be watching Mr. Putin’s talks with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Valerie Hopkins

media:content.media:credit: Manish Swarup/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India greeting each other before a meeting in New Delhi in 2021.

item.title: ¿Quién asumirá la responsabilidad de los ataques de EE. UU. a embarcaciones en aguas internacionales?
item.description: Los detalles detrás de la planificación de la ofensiva del 2 de septiembre levantarían dudas sobre el rol que jugaron un almirante y el secretario de Defensa.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Siguiendo órdenes del presidente Trump y del secretario de Defensa, Pete Hegseth, el ejército estadounidense ha atacado a 21 embarcaciones en el mar Caribe y el océano Pacífico oriental, matando a 83 personas.

item.title: Trump Renames Institute of Peace for Himself
item.description: Workers installed the president’s name on the Washington institute, thrusting it back into the spotlight as it is set to host the signing of a peace deal between Rwanda and Congo.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi

media:content.media:credit: Kevin Lamarque/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The United States Institute of Peace on Wednesday, after President Trump’s name was added to the facade.

item.title: Trump’s Former Campaign Manager Assisted Honduran Presidential Candidate
item.description: Brad Parscale advised the campaign of Nasry Asfura, a right-wing candidate who was endorsed by the U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel, David C. Adams and Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brad Parscale managed President Trump’s 2020 re-election campaign.

item.title: Former F.D.A. Commissioners Sound Alarm on Plan to Change Vaccine Policy
item.description: Twelve former commissioners, in a New England Journal of Medicine article, said they were “deeply concerned” by a leaked memo from the agency’s vaccine regulator.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, has repeatedly criticized Covid-19 vaccines as deadly despite the scientific consensus that they are safe.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the 2025 DealBook Summit
item.description: President Trump’s economic policies and artificial intelligence were among the central topics at the gathering of business and political leaders.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone, Brian O’Keefe and Bernhard Warner

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, right, speaking to Andrew Ross Sorkin, Dealbook Editor at Large, at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Newsom Warns That Trump Is ‘Trying to Wreck This Country’
item.description: The California governor weighed in on the 2028 presidential election, and called out executives for “bending the knee” to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Are U.S. Boat Strikes Near Venezuela Legal?
item.description: Lawmakers from both parties have been raising questions about the legality of U.S. military strikes on boats near Venezuela. David Sanger, White House and national security correspondent, explains.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Jon Hazell, June Kim, James Surdam and Whitney Shefte
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump Faces Choices on Russia-Ukraine Talks as Peace Deal Deadline Passes
item.description: The president wanted Moscow and Kyiv to come to terms by Thanksgiving. Negotiations are now stalled, leaving the White House to decide if an agreement is possible anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “It does take two to tango,” President Trump said after his envoys left a meeting in Moscow with no major breakthroughs in their meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Gunman Killed and 3 Officers Hurt in Shooting at Omaha Gas Station
item.description: Police say the man, whose identity has yet to be released, shot another man at a grocery store across town in what appeared to be a random attack.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

media:content.media:credit: Chris Machian/Omaha World-Herald, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Three police officers were injured during a shootout with a gunman at a gas station in Omaha.

item.title: Unpacking Trump’s Immigration Crackdown and Deportation Efforts
item.description: As Trump steps up his crackdown, our reporters explain what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Jess Bidgood

media:content.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Border Patrol vehicles near the U.S.-Mexico border in January in Sunland Park, N.M.

item.title: Afghan Refugees Face Uncertain Future As Trump Tightens Immigration Policy
item.description: Afghan immigrants in the United States believed they were safe. A deadly shooting that authorities say was carried out by an Afghan has thrown their futures into doubt.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Obaidullah Durani and his daughter, Hela, at the Arizona Refugee Center in Mesa, Ariz. Mr. Durani, a fighter pilot, arrived from Afghanistan with his two children in 2021, but his wife is still in Afghanistan.

item.title: Lawsuit Against Hispanic Scholarship Fund Argues It Discriminates Against Non-Hispanic Students
item.description: The plaintiffs, white and Asian students, said they would qualify for scholarships given out by the Hispanic Scholarship Fund, but for their race.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Mokam

media:content.media:credit: Jose Luis Magana/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Edward Blum is the president of the American Alliance for Equal Rights, which filed the lawsuit against the Hispanic Scholarship Fund on behalf of two students.

item.title: Erika Kirk Thinks Women Who Voted for Mamdani Will Delay Having Families
item.description: During the DealBook Summit, Erika Kirk, Charlie Kirk’s widow and chief executive of Turning Point USA, expressed concern for women in New York City who were putting off marriage and starting families.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Steve Cropper, Guitarist, Songwriter and Shaper of Memphis Soul Music, Dies at 84
item.description: As a member of Booker T. & the MG’s and as a producer, he played a pivotal role in the rise of Stax Records, a storied force in R&B in the 1960s and ’70s.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: (Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay (Song)

media:content.media:credit: David Reed Archive/Alamy
media:content.media:description: Steve Cropper in 1973. His guitar licks could be heard in hits by Otis Redding, Sam & Dave and Wilson Pickett, among many others.

item.title: La amenaza de Trump de una acción militar es un gran desafío para Maduro. Esto es lo que hay que saber
item.description: Según personas cercanas al gobierno venezolano, Maduro cree que puede mantener el control y sortear la amenaza más grave a sus 12 años de gobierno.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nicolás Maduro en Caracas en noviembre. Según varias personas cercanas al gobierno venezolano, Maduro cree que puede mantener el control y sortear la amenaza más grave a sus 12 años de gobierno.

item.title: Trump Plans to Lower Fuel Efficiency Requirements
item.description: Also, Dick Van Dyke shares his secrets to aging well. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Air Force Pilot Ejects as Thunderbirds F-16 Crashes in California
item.description: The pilot was in stable condition after losing control of the fighter jet near Trona, Calif., about 180 miles northeast of Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Jesus Jiménez
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Luke Hales/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Air Force Thunderbirds during a flyover in Chicago in August.

item.title: Restaurant Review: Yamada
item.description: This week Ligaya Mishan, one of The New York Times’s chief restaurant critics, reviewed Yamada. This unshowy restaurant in Manhattan’s Chinatown exemplifies the subtle art of the most rarefied form of Japanese cooking.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Cooking

media:content.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The last course is wagashi, here a tiny mountain of sweet bean paste, purple from ube, under a moon of candied chestnut with a touch of gold.

item.title: Repatriation Flights With Hundreds of Migrants Arrive in Venezuela
item.description: The flights with Venezuelans who had been living in the United States arrived at a time of airspace safety concerns as the U.S. military pressures Venezuela’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and María Victoria Fermín

media:content.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A plane carrying Venezuelan migrants landing at the Simón Bolívar International Airport in Maiquetía, Venezuela, on Wednesday.

item.title: For MrBeast, YouTube Still Rules, but It’s Not Everything
item.description: The social media star has created a vast and varied business empire with big expansion plans.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jimmy Donaldson, known as MrBeast, at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: An Alaskan Village Confronts Its Changing Climate: Rebuild or Relocate?
item.description: After a devastating storm, the people who fled a remote coastal village face an existential question.

media:content.media:credit: Katie Basile for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Maggie Paul, in her hotel room at the Aspen Suites in Anchorage, Alaska, after her home was destroyed by Typhoon Halong. However long it takes to put the decimated village back together, Ms. Paul said, “I will wait.”

item.title: In Yemen, Separatist Forces Backed by UAE March Into Oil-Rich Region
item.description: The separatists were battling to secure the region’s oil fields, residents and the group’s officials said. Their swift advance could be a turning point in Yemen’s decade-long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Nereim

media:content.media:credit: Reuters
media:content.media:description: Forces from Yemen’s separatist Southern Transitional Council being redeployed from the southern province of Abyan in 2020.

item.title: China apela a las alianzas de la Segunda Guerra Mundial y busca apoyo en Europa contra Japón
item.description: Personal diplomático de China pidió a funcionarios británicos y franceses que estuvieran de su lado en la división que tienen con Tokio por la disputa sobre Taiwán.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson

media:content.media:credit: Ann Wang/Reuters
media:content.media:description: La bandera de Taiwán ondea sobre Taipéi, la capital, en octubre. La dirigente de Japón enfureció a China el mes pasado al sugerir que podría acudir en defensa de Taiwán si China lo atacaba.

item.title: U.S. Military’s Boat Strikes Planning Takes On New Significance
item.description: The details could raise questions about who was responsible for a follow-up strike on Sept. 2 — the commander who ordered it or the defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: On orders from President Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the U.S. military has attacked 21 boats in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, killing 83 people.

item.title: Gavin Newsom: Democrats Need to Be ‘More Culturally Normal’
item.description: During an interview at the DealBook Summit with Andrew Ross Sorkin, editor at large, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said that Democrats needed to design a compelling economic vision for the future.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
